awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Assessment of a Coal-Ash Spill in Dan River on Water Resources downstream Using Numerical Modeling
awd_abstract_narration:
1438582
Altinakar, Mustafa


This work provides a unique first opportunity to study a major coal-ash spill event while it is still happening, with the added benefits of guiding data collection efforts and immediately interpreting data to gain a better understanding of the consequences of coal ash spills on river-reservoir system, and developing mitigation strategies. Although coal ash spills have occurred many times in the past with disastrous consequences on humans, water resources and the ecosystem, this will be the first time a complete investigation based on coupled one and two-dimensional modeling of unsteady hydrodynamics, sediment transport and morphodynamics and contaminant transport and fate can be undertaken. The models established for the research will also serve for long term monitoring and development of remediation approaches. 

The research team has already published one- and two-dimensional models in the lower reaches of the Dan River/Roanoke River system, downstream from the proposed research site.  The results of this research can serve to bridge engineering and policy making by providing fundamental information of the hydraulic flow in the river systems. Several graduate students and two undergraduate work study students will be involved in this research contributing to STEM and research-based education.

The consequences of a coal ash spill into the Dan River near Eden, North Carolina, on Sunday February 2, 2014, on the water resources downstream were investigated using both a one-dimensional model of the Dan River and Kerr Reservoir system downstream of the spill location and a two dimensional model of the Kerr Reservoir. The spill event resulted from the failure of a 48-inch corrugated metal pipe under the primary storage pond at the Dan River Steam Station owned by the Duke Energy. The incident released 39,000 tons of coal ash and 27 million gallons of pond water into the Dan River. Although it is composed of mainly silicon oxide, iron oxide and aluminum oxide, the coal ash also contains arsenic, selenium, mercury, lead and some other toxic substances. The simulations with one- and two-dimensional models involved unsteady flow hydrodynamics, unsteady non equilibrium transport of bed material and coal ash in multiple size classes and the transport and fate simulations for arsenic and selenium.

One-dimensional CCHE1D software was used to model the river-reservoir system extending from USGS Wentworth gauge on Dan River located in North Carolina about 18.86 miles upstream of the spill location to the John H. Kerr Dam in Virginia located about 111.13 miles downstream of the spill location. The simulations were performed for a period two years from 1/19/2014 to 1/18/2016, by filling in the missing data for the period 3/21/2015 – 1/18/2016 by historic driest and wettest period data. Cross section data was compiled from different sources. USGS gauge data was used for water and sediment discharge boundary conditions. Measured Kerr Reservoir surface elevation was imposed as the downstream boundary condition. The spill timeline was estimated based on the information provided by the Duke Energy. Physical properties of bed material and coal ash were measured by the USACE. Bed material and coal ash were modeled using nine size classes for each, which were tracked both in the water column and the three layers of bed sediments. The two-dimensional model of the Kerr Reservoir was developed based on the available bottom topography data. The non-uniform mesh has 122,470 nodes. Bed material and coal ash were modeled using 4 and 2 size classes, respectively.

Models study results provided information on the transport and fate of coal ash and the associated contaminants, arsenic and selenium. The results showed the importance of the size classes and various manmade structures along the study reach. The Schoolfield Dam located 23.8 miles downstream of the spill location controls the movement of the coal ash. Two year after the spill, about 60% of the coal ash, consisting of medium and fine sizes, has passed to the downstream and 40%, consisting mostly the coarser sizes, remained upstream. About 15% of the coal ash enters into the Kerr Reservoir and only the finest size class, amounting to about 10%, reaches the dam. Two-dimensional modeling of Kerr Reservoir confirmed the latter findings and showed that the highest peak coal ash outflow discharge of 11.4 kg/s is observed on 3/24/2014 at 1600 hours. After April 2014, the outflow discharges rapidly decrease. Although the outflow discharge from the Kerr Dam contains trace amounts of coal ash one may consider that the initial event has ended on 11/15/2014. This is 283 days after the entry of coal ash into the reservoir and 287 days after the spill. Simulations also showed that the coal ash mixes with the bed sediments through erosion and deposition processes. The coal ash deposited in the bed may be re-suspended during high flow events.
